Award.AwardTitle: Does Incorporating Choices into Motivation Interventions Increase Their Effectiveness?

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. This postdoctoral fellowship provides an opportunity for an emerging scholar to extend innovative research in educational psychology in order to improve students' motivation and achievement in science. There is a shortage of qualified professionals with skills in advanced science and mathematics, and one critical factor that impacts students' performance in these fields is their motivation to learn. Two particular motivational issues are students not believing they are capable to succeed in their courses (i.e., having low perceived competence) and students not thinking that what they are learning is useful (i.e., having low utility value). Researchers have addressed these issues by developing educational intervention activities in which students write reflectively about topics related to their perceived competence and utility value. These interventions have improved students' motivation and achievement in many college math and science courses, and they require few resources to implement. Thus they are efficient ways to target academic outcomes at critical transition points in students? pursuit of mathematics and science careers. However, research on reflective writing motivation interventions is somewhat novel and it is possible that these interventions can be even more impactful than they are currently. One way to make them more impactful might be to give students choices while they are completing the interventions. Prior research has found that students show higher motivation and achievement if they are given choices about what to learn. The purpose of this postdoctoral fellowship is to explore whether adding choices during reflective writing motivation interventions strengthens the effectiveness of the interventions with respect to college students' motivation and achievement in biology.

The fellowship provides support to assess this objective in three studies, which utilize different types of choices. Study 1 uses secondary data analysis to assess the effects of giving students a choice of task during an intervention. Data analysis is based on a previously conducted intervention that aimed to improve students? perceptions of utility value. Some students were assigned to write a letter intended to increase utility value, other students were assigned to write a personal essay intended to increase utility value, and a third group of students chose between the two tasks. Study 2 examines the effects of giving students a choice of type of reflective writing motivation intervention, using a laboratory experiment. Some students are assigned to write an essay intended to increase their utility value, other students are assigned to write an essay intended to increase their perceived competence, and a third group of students choose between the two types of writing exercises. Study 3 replicates the Study 2 design in a classroom setting. The objectives of all three studies are: (1) To examine the effects of the intervention conditions compared to a control group, as well as to compare the effects of the choice versus non-choice intervention conditions, on students? perceived competence, utility value, and science achievement; (2) To examine whether the different conditions benefit students more who start the intervention with lower motivation to learn or lower prior achievement; (3) To test whether three mechanisms (engagement, perceptions of autonomy, or likelihood of choosing tasks that correspond to students' motivational deficits) explain any beneficial effects of choice. These studies contribute to prior literature by demonstrating whether different types of choice strengthen the impact of motivation interventions, and by shedding light on mechanisms and factors that might moderate the effects of these interventions. More broadly, this work is important because it aims to improve low-cost programs that can encourage more students towards careers in science and mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Motivation strongly affects performance in STEM fields, with two major motivational issues being a lack of perceived competence and a lack of value for learning. Researchers have developed promising educational interventions asking students to write reflectively about topics related to perceived competence and value. However, it is possible that these interventions can be even more impactful. One approach may be to give students choices while they are completing interventions. Prior research has found that students show higher motivation and achievement if they are given choices about how to learn in the classroom. In this postdoctoral fellowship, an emerging scholar examined whether adding choices to reflective writing motivation interventions might amplify their effectiveness at enhancing learning outcomes in college biology.

Study 1 used secondary data analysis to assess the effects of a choice between two tasks during a value-targeting intervention. College biology students were either assigned to complete a value-targeting intervention activity (an essay or a letter) or they chose an activity. Students who received a choice reported higher utility value and interest in biology compared to students who did not receive the choice, with interest and value promoting students’ later grades and course enrollment. A supplemental study replicated the positive effects of choices during a value-targeting intervention on interest and grades. Follow-up online studies explored further whether all types of choices were equally beneficial; results showed that even trivial choices amplified some effects of utility value interventions, although effects were limited to less-confident students. Results suggest that choices need not be intensive to be effective.

Study 2 examined the effects of a choice between two self-reflective motivation interventions, using an online study. Some individuals were assigned to write a value-targeting essay, others were assigned to write an essay targeting their perceived competence; a third group chose between the interventions. Contrary to the hypotheses, participants in choice versus no choice conditions did not differ on any outcomes. However, the two interventions also did not benefit participants compared to a control condition. The research team is conducting a supplemental follow-up study to determine whether low participant engagement contributed to the observed results.

Originally, a third study intended to examine choices between two interventions in a college biology course. Given the null findings of Study 2, the research team did not proceed with this study. Instead they examined choice, perceived value, and perceived competence in college biology using a correlational study. They coded and analyzed over 1200 interviews with students who were graduating, but who had taken a biology course two years prior. They evaluated the choices students reported making regarding pursuing biomedical careers, whether students perceived these choices as positive or negative, and how choices related to students’ perceived competence and value in biology. Results suggested that many students reflected on choices to change their future plans in positive terms, especially if they remained in biomedical fields but pursued different careers. Even if students chose to leave biomedical fields, almost 40% reflected on some positive features of this choice.

Thus far the principal investigator has published two manuscripts from the project (a third is invited for minor revision) and will write up at least two more manuscripts next year. She has also published four other journal articles (and submitted two more for review) about motivational interventions and STEM participation but not specifically about choices during the fellowship term, contributing to her emerging research identity as a motivation expert.

Intellectual merit. In educational psychology, many researchers have studied choices in educational settings; this project extends extant work to consider how choices influence the effectiveness of interventions. These studies also provide useful information regarding for whom and what kinds of choices work best, topics of current debate in the field. This work also contributes to the development of social-psychological interventions more broadly, because it points to a methodological element (the amount of choice in interventions) that can improve intervention effectiveness at a broad scale. Finally, the work informs researchers’ understanding of STEM pedagogy in college because this project sheds light on the types of instructional techniques and student experiences in biology courses that make them more or less willing to continue pursuing studies in these fields.

Broader impacts. This work’s primary aim is to improve low-cost programs that encourage more students towards careers in science and mathematics, and as such it contributes to the development of activities that increase STEM participation directly. Of particular importance, prior research has found that motivationally-supportive interventions promote outcomes most strongly for students who have lower initial achievement or who are underrepresented in a given field, so this work helps to create optimal versions of intervention programs that aim to broaden representation of students from various gender and ethnic backgrounds in advanced STEM studies.
